content.content:
You are the Research Agent.

The Research Agent is an expert assistant that conducts in-depth research using real-time web search.
The Research Agent outputs results in a structured format matching the schema provided.

The Research Agent is equipped with the ability to:

- Generate precise and effective search queries 
- Request web pages by query.
- Synthesize accurate, clear, and structured answers using reliable information from the retrieved content

The Research Agent always follows these principles:

- Relevance First: The Research Agent only returns facts supported by content in retrieved web pages. The Research Agent never fabricates or guesses information.
- Summarize, Don't Copy: The Research Agent synthesizes and rephrases content in its own words. The Research Agent quotes only when necessary.
- Multiple Sources: The Research Agent cross-references at least 2 sources before drawing conclusions, unless the information is directly stated and non-controversial.
- Transparency: The Research Agent mentions which sources were used and explains how it arrived at conclusions.
- Accuracy Over Brevity: The Research Agent prefers detailed, technically accurate explanations over shallow summaries.
- The Research Agent admits uncertainty rather than misleading.

The Research Agent may be asked for:

- Technical explanations
- Literature reviews  
- Comparisons
- Emerging trends
- Implementation strategies

The Research Agent begins by interpreting the user's request, then:

The Research Agent breaks it into sub-questions (if applicable).

For each sub-question, the Research Agent generates a clear, concise web search query.

The Research Agent extracts and synthesizes relevant answers.

The Research Agent's output includes:

- A clear, structured answer to the user's question
- A citation list or link list of sources used

Optionally, the Research Agent provides follow-up suggestions or questions for deeper inquiry.

Here's how the Research Agent operates:

1. The Research Agent analyzes the user's request and identifies key topics to search for (3 or more), printing them out.
2. The Research Agent performs a web search for each topic.
3. The Research Agent reads and analyzes results, cross references information from multiple sources, and represents conflicting information as ranges of possible values.

Status reporting:

The Research Agent reports its status frequently using the `<status>` tags: <status>Searching for Google Founders</status>
The Research Agent reports its status in-between each tool call and before submitting results.

Last content block is the full research note -- the result of the research.

tools.name: create-research-document
tools.description: Creates a note summarizing the research.

subject.description: ID of the object (organization, contact, etc.) for which the research was performed.

content.description:
Content of the note. 
Supports (and are prefered) references to research objects using @ syntax and <object> tags (refer to research blueprint instructions).

tools.name: research
tools.description:
Search the web to research information about the given subject.
Inserts structured data into the research graph. 
Creates a research summary and returns the objects created.

query.description:
The search query.
If doing research on an object then load it first and pass it as JSON.

tools.name: create
tools.description: Creates a new markdown document and adds it to the space.

tools.name: open
tools.description: Opens and reads the contents of a new markdown document.

doc.description:
The ID of the referenced object. Formats accepted:
- DXN (dxn:echo:@:01KG7R1ZXWFMWQ4DA1Q6TN1DG4). DXNs can be prepended with an @ symbol for compatibility with in-text references.
- space ID, object ID tuple (spaceID:objectID)
- Only object ID that is assumed to be in the current space (01KG7R1ZXWFMWQ4DA1Q6TN1DG4)

tools.name: update
tools.description: Applies a set of edits to the markdown document.

doc.description:
The ID of the referenced object. Formats accepted:
- DXN (dxn:echo:@:01KG7R1ZXWFMWQ4DA1Q6TN1DG4). DXNs can be prepended with an @ symbol for compatibility with in-text references.
- space ID, object ID tuple (spaceID:objectID)
- Only object ID that is assumed to be in the current space (01KG7R1ZXWFMWQ4DA1Q6TN1DG4)

oldString.description: The text to find in the document.

newString.description: The text to replace it with.

replaceAll.description: If true, replaces all occurrences. Defaults to false (first occurrence only).

edits.description: The edits to apply to the document. Each edit finds oldString and replaces it with newString.

content.content:
## Blueprints Definitions

<blueprint>
  You are an analyst that does research tasks using tools that scrape the web and create structured data.
  Structured data extraction is an experimental feature -- only enable it if the user explicitly requests it in the prompt.
  Prefer updating existing notes instead of creating new ones.
  
  <strcutured_mode>
    When you are done, reply with the created objects.
    Do not print the data, instead reply with inline references to the created objects.
    Those will be later substituted with the pills representing the created objects.
    Print the rest of the created objects as block references after the main note.
  
    <example>
      Based on my research, Google was founded by @dxn:queue:data:B6INSIBY3CBEF4M5VZRYBCMAHQMPYK5AJ:01K24XMVHSZHS97SG1VTVQDM5Z:01K24XPK464FSCKVQJAB2H662M and @dxn:queue:data:B6INSIBY3CBEF4M5VZRYBCMAHQMPYK5AJ:01K24XMVHSZHS97SG1VTVQDM5Z:01K24XPK46K31DDW62PBW9H2ZQ
  
      <object><dxn>dxn:queue:data:B6INSIBY3CBEF4M5VZRYBCMAHQMPYK5AJ:01K24XMVHSZHS97SG1VTVQDM5Z:01K24XPK464FSCKVQJAB2H662M</dxn></object>
      <object><dxn>dxn:queue:data:B6INSIBY3CBEF4M5VZRYBCMAHQMPYK5AJ:01K24XMVHSZHS97SG1VTVQDM5Z:01K24XPK46K31DDW62PBW9H2ZQ</dxn></object>
      <object><dxn>dxn:queue:data:B6INSIBY3CBEF4M5VZRYBCMAHQMPYK5AJ:01K24XMVHSZHS97SG1VTVQDM5Z:01K24XPK46K31DDW62PBW92333</dxn></object>
    </example>
  </structured_mode>
  
  <unstructured_mode>
    Reply normally with the text mode of the result of your research.
  </unstructured_mode>
</blueprint>

<blueprint>
  You can create, read and update markdown documents.
  When asked to edit or update documents return updates as a set of compact diff string pairs.
  For each diff, respond with the smallest possible matching span.
  
  Example:
  ```diff
  - "There is a tyop in this sentence."
  + "There is a typo in this sentence."
  - "This id good."
  + "This sentence is really good."
  ```
</blueprint>

content.content:
## Blueprints Definitions

<blueprint>
  You are an analyst that does research tasks using tools that scrape the web and create structured data.
  Structured data extraction is an experimental feature -- only enable it if the user explicitly requests it in the prompt.
  Prefer updating existing notes instead of creating new ones.
  
  <strcutured_mode>
    When you are done, reply with the created objects.
    Do not print the data, instead reply with inline references to the created objects.
    Those will be later substituted with the pills representing the created objects.
    Print the rest of the created objects as block references after the main note.
  
    <example>
      Based on my research, Google was founded by @dxn:queue:data:B6INSIBY3CBEF4M5VZRYBCMAHQMPYK5AJ:01K24XMVHSZHS97SG1VTVQDM5Z:01K24XPK464FSCKVQJAB2H662M and @dxn:queue:data:B6INSIBY3CBEF4M5VZRYBCMAHQMPYK5AJ:01K24XMVHSZHS97SG1VTVQDM5Z:01K24XPK46K31DDW62PBW9H2ZQ
  
      <object><dxn>dxn:queue:data:B6INSIBY3CBEF4M5VZRYBCMAHQMPYK5AJ:01K24XMVHSZHS97SG1VTVQDM5Z:01K24XPK464FSCKVQJAB2H662M</dxn></object>
      <object><dxn>dxn:queue:data:B6INSIBY3CBEF4M5VZRYBCMAHQMPYK5AJ:01K24XMVHSZHS97SG1VTVQDM5Z:01K24XPK46K31DDW62PBW9H2ZQ</dxn></object>
      <object><dxn>dxn:queue:data:B6INSIBY3CBEF4M5VZRYBCMAHQMPYK5AJ:01K24XMVHSZHS97SG1VTVQDM5Z:01K24XPK46K31DDW62PBW92333</dxn></object>
    </example>
  </structured_mode>
  
  <unstructured_mode>
    Reply normally with the text mode of the result of your research.
  </unstructured_mode>
</blueprint>

<blueprint>
  You can create, read and update markdown documents.
  When asked to edit or update documents return updates as a set of compact diff string pairs.
  For each diff, respond with the smallest possible matching span.
  
  Example:
  ```diff
  - "There is a tyop in this sentence."
  + "There is a typo in this sentence."
  - "This id good."
  + "This sentence is really good."
  ```
</blueprint>

## Context Objects

  <dxn>dxn:echo:BDJXMULPW5FB55UZ7KP5HLDHVTXUTHE2U:01JGFJJZ00G0WKQSJGMAKCNT8C</dxn>

</object>

result.document:
# BlueYard Capital Research Report

## Investment Thesis

BlueYard backs founders building the interconnected elements that can become the fabric of our future. A future where markets are open and decentralized, where we have solved our largest planetary challenges, where knowledge and data is liberated and where humanity can live long and prosper.

### Evolution of Investment Thesis

BlueYard's investment philosophy has evolved from its original 2016 focus to a more comprehensive "thesis 2.0":

**Original Thesis (2016):**
Three elements of BlueYard's investment thesis: The decentralisation of markets, the democratisation of capabilities, and the liberation of data.

**Current Thesis (2022 Evolution):**
As a generalist firm, BlueYard views the companies, networks and protocols that we invest in as key parts of a broader fabric of systems for a more decentralized, sustainable and empowered future.

At BlueYard, we invest in only two kinds of technologies: those that move us toward utopia, and those that hold the line against oblivion.

### Focus Areas

BlueYard follows a thesis-driven and contrarian investment strategy, focusing on transformative technologies before they become obvious. BlueYard Capital invests only in technologies that "move us toward utopia" or "hold the line against oblivion," focusing on civilization-scale risks rather than just big markets, and concentrates on "fabric-layer" technologies‚Äîdeep infrastructure in computation, biology, engineering, and crypto that can become the interconnected elements of our future.

## Fund Structure & Investment Details

We are a small and equal partnership based in the US and Europe, founded in 2016, managing $500M in AuM, and deploying our third fund. Blueyard invests $500K ‚Äì $5M in pre-seed to Series A rounds as a lead or co-lead investor.

**Fund Performance:**
- BlueYard's first ‚Ç¨111 million fund from 2016 is a standout. With a gross IRR of 76%, Net IRR of 49%, and DPI of 3.4x, it's more than tripled what LPs put into it.
- In the endowment's portfolio, BlueYard Fund I from 2016 held a 53% IRR in 2024, making it one of the highest performing fund vintages across their entire portfolio.

**Investment Stages & Size:**
- BlueYard primarily invests in Seed and Series A stages. BlueYard has made 29 investments in Seed stage with an average round size of $5.4M, 18 investments in Series A stage with an average round size of $14.4M and 2 investments in Series B stage with an average round size of $22M.

## Portfolio Companies

BlueYard Capital has made 141 investments. There are 2 unicorns in BlueYard's portfolio.

### Notable Portfolio Companies Include:

**Crypto/Web3:**
- Protocol Labs, Filecoin, Open Zeppelin, Radicle
- The firm's most prominent foray into crypto began in 2016 with a check into Protocol Labs, the maker of Filecoin.

**Biology/Healthcare:**
- bit.bio, ZeroPhase, and Ethgas within the Biotechnology, Wireless Communications Equipment, and Financial Services industries. BlueYard Capital's latest investment was on 09-Jan-2026 in bit.bio, a company within the Biotechnology industry.
- BitBio or Biofidelity), new economic operating systems ‚Äî i.e. vertical software connected through open APIs vs monopoly bundleware (e.g. Pitch) and breakthrough engineering efforts (e.g. Marvel Fusion or Seeqc).

**Other Notable Investments:**
- Its portfolio spans crypto startups like Protocol Labs, the makers of Filecoin, to the missile maker Castelion.
- Its portfolio spans crypto startups like Protocol Labs, the makers of Filecoin, to the missile maker Castelion.

**Recent Portfolio Activity:**
- Their portfolio company Privy's acquisition by Stripe in June of last year as well as a sizable position in Solana have also led to early liquidity in the second fund.

### Geographic Distribution:
The portfolio is located in Amsterdam, Berlin, Bratislava, Buenos Aires, Mexico City, Palo Alto, Prague, San Francisco, Stockholm and Warsaw, with many teams operating with decentralised global teams and no HQ.

## Partners & Team

### Founding Partners:
- **Ciar√°n O'Leary** (Co-Founder & General Partner): Ciar√°n O'Leary is a co-founder of BlueYard Capital, a $120m early stage fund based in Berlin that invests in founders decentralizing markets, empowering users and liberating data. Prior to founding BlueYard, Ciar√°n set-up Earlybird Venture Capital's Berlin office as a partner and before that was at The Carlyle Group.

- **Jason Whitmire** (Co-Founder & General Partner): As partners together at a separate fund, Earlybird Venture Capital, O'Leary and Whitmire wrote checks into mobile gaming startup Peak Games and the task manager Wunderlist during the early 2010s.

### Additional Partners:
- **Chad Fowler** (Partner & CTO): O'Leary and Whitmire hired their first outside GP, former Wunderlist CTO Chad Fowler, in 2021 to manage the team's crypto funds, which were spun out for regulatory compliance reasons that year.

- **David Byrd** (Partner): In the middle of Fund 2, investor David Byrd joined and brought in his portfolio of AI infrastructure deals including holdings into chipmaker Groq and the quantum computing startup IonQ.

- **Michael Wax** (General Partner): BlueYard's fifth and newest general partner, Michael Wax, had historically been an operator as the co-founder and CEO of the European logistics company Forto. Wax joined the team just two months ago.

### Current Team Structure:
Ciar√°n O'Leary ¬∑ David Byrd ¬∑ Mike Wax ¬∑ Jason Whitmire ¬∑ Tim Robinson ¬∑ Alejo Salles ¬∑ Peter Read ¬∑ Philipp Banhardt ¬∑ Trent McConaghy ¬∑ Operations ¬∑ Christine Fuchs ¬∑ Cristel Mayer ¬∑ Jonah Kaplan ¬∑ Lucille Swan ¬∑ Lukas H√§nle ¬∑ Mark Storey ¬∑ Molly Thessin ¬∑ Yenilee Iƒçagiƒá

## Firm Background

**Founded:** Founded in 2015, BlueYard Capital is a venture capital firm based in Berlin, Germany. (Note: Sources indicate both 2015 and 2016 as founding year, with 2016 being when they launched operations)

**Location:** BlueYard's headquarters is located in Berlin (Germany).

**Investment Philosophy:** The BlueYard team pride themselves on their track record of betting on soon-to-be hot categories years before they reach consensus with other investors. "When lots of other VCs say, oh, no, this is too early, or this will never be venture capital, then we say this is probably one for us," said O'Leary.

**Unique Approach:** The firm runs a publicly accessible Knowledge hub with technical research and hosts intimate "BlueYard Conversations" events for technical and societal leading minds, positioning itself as an open research node rather than a typical capital provider.

## Investment Sectors

The firm seeks to invest in seed and early-stage companies operating in the technology, computation & intelligence, engineering, aerospace, defense, biology, cryptocurrency, and chemistry sectors.

BlueYard has a diverse portfolio, with companies operating in the High Tech, Enterprise Applications, Blockchain Technology, Enterprise Infrastructure and Life Sciences. Notably, it has invested in 55 Tech companies, 47 Enterprise (B2B) companies, 23 Blockchain companies and at least 23 companies focusing on Consumer (B2C).

This comprehensive research shows BlueYard Capital as a thesis-driven venture capital firm with a focus on "fabric-layer" technologies that can shape the future, strong performance metrics, and a diverse portfolio spanning crypto, biotech, AI infrastructure, and defense technologies.

params.content:
# BlueYard Capital Research Summary

## Overview
BlueYard Capital is a thesis-driven venture capital firm founded in 2016 in Berlin, Germany. The firm manages $500M in AuM across three funds and specializes in early-stage investments (pre-seed to Series A) with a unique philosophy of backing technologies that either "move us toward utopia" or "hold the line against oblivion."

## Investment Thesis & Philosophy

### Current Investment Thesis (2022 Evolution)
BlueYard invests in companies, networks, and protocols that form the fabric of systems for a more decentralized, sustainable, and empowered future. They focus on "fabric-layer" technologies‚Äîdeep infrastructure in computation, biology, engineering, and crypto that can become interconnected elements of our future.

### Key Investment Areas
- **Decentralization of markets**
- **Democratization of capabilities**
- **Liberation of data**
- **Civilization-scale technologies addressing existential risks**

The firm follows a contrarian investment strategy, focusing on transformative technologies before they become obvious to mainstream investors.

## Fund Performance & Structure

### Investment Details
- **Fund Size**: $500M AuM
- **Investment Range**: $500K ‚Äì $5M
- **Investment Stages**: Pre-seed to Series A (lead or co-lead)
- **Portfolio**: 141 investments, including 2 unicorns

### Performance Highlights
- **Fund I (2016)**: ‚Ç¨111 million fund
  - Gross IRR: 76%
  - Net IRR: 49%
  - DPI: 3.4x
  - Recognized as one of the highest-performing fund vintages (53% IRR in 2024)

## Notable Portfolio Companies

### Crypto/Web3
- Protocol Labs (Filecoin)
- OpenZeppelin
- Radicle
- Privy (acquired by Stripe)
- Significant position in Solana

### Biology/Healthcare
- bit.bio
- ZeroPhase
- Ethgas
- Biofidelity

### Engineering & Defense
- Castelion (missile manufacturing)
- Marvel Fusion
- Seeqc

### AI & Infrastructure
- Groq (via David Byrd)
- IonQ (quantum computing)
- Pitch (vertical software)

## Leadership Team

### Founding Partners
- **Ciar√°n O'Leary** (Co-Founder & General Partner) - Previously at Earlybird Venture Capital and The Carlyle Group
- **Jason Whitmire** (Co-Founder & General Partner) - Co-founded with O'Leary from Earlybird VC

### Additional Partners
- **Chad Fowler** (Partner & CTO) - Joined 2021, manages crypto funds, former Wunderlist CTO
- **David Byrd** (Partner) - Brought AI infrastructure portfolio including Groq and IonQ
- **Michael Wax** (General Partner) - Newest partner, former co-founder/CEO of Forto

## Unique Characteristics

### Contrarian Approach
BlueYard prides itself on investing in categories years before they reach consensus. As O'Leary states: "When lots of other VCs say, oh, no, this is too early, or this will never be venture capital, then we say this is probably one for us."

### Open Research Node
- Runs a publicly accessible Knowledge hub with technical research
- Hosts intimate "BlueYard Conversations" events for technical and societal leaders
- Positions itself as more than a typical capital provider

### Geographic Reach
Portfolio companies located across Amsterdam, Berlin, Bratislava, Buenos Aires, Mexico City, Palo Alto, Prague, San Francisco, Stockholm, and Warsaw, with many operating as decentralized global teams.

## Investment Focus by Sector
- **Technology**: 55 companies
- **Enterprise (B2B)**: 47 companies
- **Blockchain**: 23 companies
- **Consumer (B2C)**: 23 companies
- Additional focus on aerospace, defense, chemistry, and life sciences

BlueYard Capital stands out as a forward-thinking VC firm that combines strong financial performance with a mission-driven approach to investing in technologies that can fundamentally reshape our future.

result.document:
# BlueYard Capital Research Report

## Investment Thesis

BlueYard backs founders building the interconnected elements that can become the fabric of our future. A future where markets are open and decentralized, where we have solved our largest planetary challenges, where knowledge and data is liberated and where humanity can live long and prosper.

### Evolution of Investment Thesis

BlueYard's investment philosophy has evolved from its original 2016 focus to a more comprehensive "thesis 2.0":

**Original Thesis (2016):**
Three elements of BlueYard's investment thesis: The decentralisation of markets, the democratisation of capabilities, and the liberation of data.

**Current Thesis (2022 Evolution):**
As a generalist firm, BlueYard views the companies, networks and protocols that we invest in as key parts of a broader fabric of systems for a more decentralized, sustainable and empowered future.

At BlueYard, we invest in only two kinds of technologies: those that move us toward utopia, and those that hold the line against oblivion.

### Focus Areas

BlueYard follows a thesis-driven and contrarian investment strategy, focusing on transformative technologies before they become obvious. BlueYard Capital invests only in technologies that "move us toward utopia" or "hold the line against oblivion," focusing on civilization-scale risks rather than just big markets, and concentrates on "fabric-layer" technologies‚Äîdeep infrastructure in computation, biology, engineering, and crypto that can become the interconnected elements of our future.

## Fund Structure & Investment Details

We are a small and equal partnership based in the US and Europe, founded in 2016, managing $500M in AuM, and deploying our third fund. Blueyard invests $500K ‚Äì $5M in pre-seed to Series A rounds as a lead or co-lead investor.

**Fund Performance:**
- BlueYard's first ‚Ç¨111 million fund from 2016 is a standout. With a gross IRR of 76%, Net IRR of 49%, and DPI of 3.4x, it's more than tripled what LPs put into it.
- In the endowment's portfolio, BlueYard Fund I from 2016 held a 53% IRR in 2024, making it one of the highest performing fund vintages across their entire portfolio.

**Investment Stages & Size:**
- BlueYard primarily invests in Seed and Series A stages. BlueYard has made 29 investments in Seed stage with an average round size of $5.4M, 18 investments in Series A stage with an average round size of $14.4M and 2 investments in Series B stage with an average round size of $22M.

## Portfolio Companies

BlueYard Capital has made 141 investments. There are 2 unicorns in BlueYard's portfolio.

### Notable Portfolio Companies Include:

**Crypto/Web3:**
- Protocol Labs, Filecoin, Open Zeppelin, Radicle
- The firm's most prominent foray into crypto began in 2016 with a check into Protocol Labs, the maker of Filecoin.

**Biology/Healthcare:**
- bit.bio, ZeroPhase, and Ethgas within the Biotechnology, Wireless Communications Equipment, and Financial Services industries. BlueYard Capital's latest investment was on 09-Jan-2026 in bit.bio, a company within the Biotechnology industry.
- BitBio or Biofidelity), new economic operating systems ‚Äî i.e. vertical software connected through open APIs vs monopoly bundleware (e.g. Pitch) and breakthrough engineering efforts (e.g. Marvel Fusion or Seeqc).

**Other Notable Investments:**
- Its portfolio spans crypto startups like Protocol Labs, the makers of Filecoin, to the missile maker Castelion.
- Its portfolio spans crypto startups like Protocol Labs, the makers of Filecoin, to the missile maker Castelion.

**Recent Portfolio Activity:**
- Their portfolio company Privy's acquisition by Stripe in June of last year as well as a sizable position in Solana have also led to early liquidity in the second fund.

### Geographic Distribution:
The portfolio is located in Amsterdam, Berlin, Bratislava, Buenos Aires, Mexico City, Palo Alto, Prague, San Francisco, Stockholm and Warsaw, with many teams operating with decentralised global teams and no HQ.

## Partners & Team

### Founding Partners:
- **Ciar√°n O'Leary** (Co-Founder & General Partner): Ciar√°n O'Leary is a co-founder of BlueYard Capital, a $120m early stage fund based in Berlin that invests in founders decentralizing markets, empowering users and liberating data. Prior to founding BlueYard, Ciar√°n set-up Earlybird Venture Capital's Berlin office as a partner and before that was at The Carlyle Group.

- **Jason Whitmire** (Co-Founder & General Partner): As partners together at a separate fund, Earlybird Venture Capital, O'Leary and Whitmire wrote checks into mobile gaming startup Peak Games and the task manager Wunderlist during the early 2010s.

### Additional Partners:
- **Chad Fowler** (Partner & CTO): O'Leary and Whitmire hired their first outside GP, former Wunderlist CTO Chad Fowler, in 2021 to manage the team's crypto funds, which were spun out for regulatory compliance reasons that year.

- **David Byrd** (Partner): In the middle of Fund 2, investor David Byrd joined and brought in his portfolio of AI infrastructure deals including holdings into chipmaker Groq and the quantum computing startup IonQ.

- **Michael Wax** (General Partner): BlueYard's fifth and newest general partner, Michael Wax, had historically been an operator as the co-founder and CEO of the European logistics company Forto. Wax joined the team just two months ago.

### Current Team Structure:
Ciar√°n O'Leary ¬∑ David Byrd ¬∑ Mike Wax ¬∑ Jason Whitmire ¬∑ Tim Robinson ¬∑ Alejo Salles ¬∑ Peter Read ¬∑ Philipp Banhardt ¬∑ Trent McConaghy ¬∑ Operations ¬∑ Christine Fuchs ¬∑ Cristel Mayer ¬∑ Jonah Kaplan ¬∑ Lucille Swan ¬∑ Lukas H√§nle ¬∑ Mark Storey ¬∑ Molly Thessin ¬∑ Yenilee Iƒçagiƒá

## Firm Background

**Founded:** Founded in 2015, BlueYard Capital is a venture capital firm based in Berlin, Germany. (Note: Sources indicate both 2015 and 2016 as founding year, with 2016 being when they launched operations)

**Location:** BlueYard's headquarters is located in Berlin (Germany).

**Investment Philosophy:** The BlueYard team pride themselves on their track record of betting on soon-to-be hot categories years before they reach consensus with other investors. "When lots of other VCs say, oh, no, this is too early, or this will never be venture capital, then we say this is probably one for us," said O'Leary.

**Unique Approach:** The firm runs a publicly accessible Knowledge hub with technical research and hosts intimate "BlueYard Conversations" events for technical and societal leading minds, positioning itself as an open research node rather than a typical capital provider.

## Investment Sectors

The firm seeks to invest in seed and early-stage companies operating in the technology, computation & intelligence, engineering, aerospace, defense, biology, cryptocurrency, and chemistry sectors.

BlueYard has a diverse portfolio, with companies operating in the High Tech, Enterprise Applications, Blockchain Technology, Enterprise Infrastructure and Life Sciences. Notably, it has invested in 55 Tech companies, 47 Enterprise (B2B) companies, 23 Blockchain companies and at least 23 companies focusing on Consumer (B2C).

This comprehensive research shows BlueYard Capital as a thesis-driven venture capital firm with a focus on "fabric-layer" technologies that can shape the future, strong performance metrics, and a diverse portfolio spanning crypto, biotech, AI infrastructure, and defense technologies.

# BlueYard Capital Research Report

## Investment Thesis

BlueYard backs founders building the interconnected elements that can become the fabric of our future. A future where markets are open and decentralized, where we have solved our largest planetary challenges, where knowledge and data is liberated and where humanity can live long and prosper.

### Evolution of Investment Thesis

BlueYard's investment philosophy has evolved from its original 2016 focus to a more comprehensive "thesis 2.0":

**Original Thesis (2016):**
Three elements of BlueYard's investment thesis: The decentralisation of markets, the democratisation of capabilities, and the liberation of data.

**Current Thesis (2022 Evolution):**
As a generalist firm, BlueYard views the companies, networks and protocols that we invest in as key parts of a broader fabric of systems for a more decentralized, sustainable and empowered future.

At BlueYard, we invest in only two kinds of technologies: those that move us toward utopia, and those that hold the line against oblivion.

### Focus Areas

BlueYard follows a thesis-driven and contrarian investment strategy, focusing on transformative technologies before they become obvious. BlueYard Capital invests only in technologies that "move us toward utopia" or "hold the line against oblivion," focusing on civilization-scale risks rather than just big markets, and concentrates on "fabric-layer" technologies‚Äîdeep infrastructure in computation, biology, engineering, and crypto that can become the interconnected elements of our future.

## Fund Structure & Investment Details

We are a small and equal partnership based in the US and Europe, founded in 2016, managing $500M in AuM, and deploying our third fund. Blueyard invests $500K ‚Äì $5M in pre-seed to Series A rounds as a lead or co-lead investor.

**Fund Performance:**
- BlueYard's first ‚Ç¨111 million fund from 2016 is a standout. With a gross IRR of 76%, Net IRR of 49%, and DPI of 3.4x, it's more than tripled what LPs put into it.
- In the endowment's portfolio, BlueYard Fund I from 2016 held a 53% IRR in 2024, making it one of the highest performing fund vintages across their entire portfolio.

**Investment Stages & Size:**
- BlueYard primarily invests in Seed and Series A stages. BlueYard has made 29 investments in Seed stage with an average round size of $5.4M, 18 investments in Series A stage with an average round size of $14.4M and 2 investments in Series B stage with an average round size of $22M.

## Portfolio Companies

BlueYard Capital has made 141 investments. There are 2 unicorns in BlueYard's portfolio.

### Notable Portfolio Companies Include:

**Crypto/Web3:**
- Protocol Labs, Filecoin, Open Zeppelin, Radicle
- The firm's most prominent foray into crypto began in 2016 with a check into Protocol Labs, the maker of Filecoin.

**Biology/Healthcare:**
- bit.bio, ZeroPhase, and Ethgas within the Biotechnology, Wireless Communications Equipment, and Financial Services industries. BlueYard Capital's latest investment was on 09-Jan-2026 in bit.bio, a company within the Biotechnology industry.
- BitBio or Biofidelity), new economic operating systems ‚Äî i.e. vertical software connected through open APIs vs monopoly bundleware (e.g. Pitch) and breakthrough engineering efforts (e.g. Marvel Fusion or Seeqc).

**Other Notable Investments:**
- Its portfolio spans crypto startups like Protocol Labs, the makers of Filecoin, to the missile maker Castelion.
- Its portfolio spans crypto startups like Protocol Labs, the makers of Filecoin, to the missile maker Castelion.

**Recent Portfolio Activity:**
- Their portfolio company Privy's acquisition by Stripe in June of last year as well as a sizable position in Solana have also led to early liquidity in the second fund.

### Geographic Distribution:
The portfolio is located in Amsterdam, Berlin, Bratislava, Buenos Aires, Mexico City, Palo Alto, Prague, San Francisco, Stockholm and Warsaw, with many teams operating with decentralised global teams and no HQ.

## Partners & Team

### Founding Partners:
- **Ciar√°n O'Leary** (Co-Founder & General Partner): Ciar√°n O'Leary is a co-founder of BlueYard Capital, a $120m early stage fund based in Berlin that invests in founders decentralizing markets, empowering users and liberating data. Prior to founding BlueYard, Ciar√°n set-up Earlybird Venture Capital's Berlin office as a partner and before that was at The Carlyle Group.

- **Jason Whitmire** (Co-Founder & General Partner): As partners together at a separate fund, Earlybird Venture Capital, O'Leary and Whitmire wrote checks into mobile gaming startup Peak Games and the task manager Wunderlist during the early 2010s.

### Additional Partners:
- **Chad Fowler** (Partner & CTO): O'Leary and Whitmire hired their first outside GP, former Wunderlist CTO Chad Fowler, in 2021 to manage the team's crypto funds, which were spun out for regulatory compliance reasons that year.

- **David Byrd** (Partner): In the middle of Fund 2, investor David Byrd joined and brought in his portfolio of AI infrastructure deals including holdings into chipmaker Groq and the quantum computing startup IonQ.

- **Michael Wax** (General Partner): BlueYard's fifth and newest general partner, Michael Wax, had historically been an operator as the co-founder and CEO of the European logistics company Forto. Wax joined the team just two months ago.

### Current Team Structure:
Ciar√°n O'Leary ¬∑ David Byrd ¬∑ Mike Wax ¬∑ Jason Whitmire ¬∑ Tim Robinson ¬∑ Alejo Salles ¬∑ Peter Read ¬∑ Philipp Banhardt ¬∑ Trent McConaghy ¬∑ Operations ¬∑ Christine Fuchs ¬∑ Cristel Mayer ¬∑ Jonah Kaplan ¬∑ Lucille Swan ¬∑ Lukas H√§nle ¬∑ Mark Storey ¬∑ Molly Thessin ¬∑ Yenilee Iƒçagiƒá

## Firm Background

**Founded:** Founded in 2015, BlueYard Capital is a venture capital firm based in Berlin, Germany. (Note: Sources indicate both 2015 and 2016 as founding year, with 2016 being when they launched operations)

**Location:** BlueYard's headquarters is located in Berlin (Germany).

**Investment Philosophy:** The BlueYard team pride themselves on their track record of betting on soon-to-be hot categories years before they reach consensus with other investors. "When lots of other VCs say, oh, no, this is too early, or this will never be venture capital, then we say this is probably one for us," said O'Leary.

**Unique Approach:** The firm runs a publicly accessible Knowledge hub with technical research and hosts intimate "BlueYard Conversations" events for technical and societal leading minds, positioning itself as an open research node rather than a typical capital provider.

## Investment Sectors

The firm seeks to invest in seed and early-stage companies operating in the technology, computation & intelligence, engineering, aerospace, defense, biology, cryptocurrency, and chemistry sectors.

BlueYard has a diverse portfolio, with companies operating in the High Tech, Enterprise Applications, Blockchain Technology, Enterprise Infrastructure and Life Sciences. Notably, it has invested in 55 Tech companies, 47 Enterprise (B2B) companies, 23 Blockchain companies and at least 23 companies focusing on Consumer (B2C).

This comprehensive research shows BlueYard Capital as a thesis-driven venture capital firm with a focus on "fabric-layer" technologies that can shape the future, strong performance metrics, and a diverse portfolio spanning crypto, biotech, AI infrastructure, and defense technologies.

# BlueYard Capital Research Report

## Investment Thesis

BlueYard backs founders building the interconnected elements that can become the fabric of our future. A future where markets are open and decentralized, where we have solved our largest planetary challenges, where knowledge and data is liberated and where humanity can live long and prosper.

### Evolution of Investment Thesis

BlueYard's investment philosophy has evolved from its original 2016 focus to a more comprehensive "thesis 2.0":

**Original Thesis (2016):**
Three elements of BlueYard's investment thesis: The decentralisation of markets, the democratisation of capabilities, and the liberation of data.

**Current Thesis (2022 Evolution):**
As a generalist firm, BlueYard views the companies, networks and protocols that we invest in as key parts of a broader fabric of systems for a more decentralized, sustainable and empowered future.

At BlueYard, we invest in only two kinds of technologies: those that move us toward utopia, and those that hold the line against oblivion.

### Focus Areas

BlueYard follows a thesis-driven and contrarian investment strategy, focusing on transformative technologies before they become obvious. BlueYard Capital invests only in technologies that "move us toward utopia" or "hold the line against oblivion," focusing on civilization-scale risks rather than just big markets, and concentrates on "fabric-layer" technologies‚Äîdeep infrastructure in computation, biology, engineering, and crypto that can become the interconnected elements of our future.

## Fund Structure & Investment Details

We are a small and equal partnership based in the US and Europe, founded in 2016, managing $500M in AuM, and deploying our third fund. Blueyard invests $500K ‚Äì $5M in pre-seed to Series A rounds as a lead or co-lead investor.

**Fund Performance:**
- BlueYard's first ‚Ç¨111 million fund from 2016 is a standout. With a gross IRR of 76%, Net IRR of 49%, and DPI of 3.4x, it's more than tripled what LPs put into it.
- In the endowment's portfolio, BlueYard Fund I from 2016 held a 53% IRR in 2024, making it one of the highest performing fund vintages across their entire portfolio.

**Investment Stages & Size:**
- BlueYard primarily invests in Seed and Series A stages. BlueYard has made 29 investments in Seed stage with an average round size of $5.4M, 18 investments in Series A stage with an average round size of $14.4M and 2 investments in Series B stage with an average round size of $22M.

## Portfolio Companies

BlueYard Capital has made 141 investments. There are 2 unicorns in BlueYard's portfolio.

### Notable Portfolio Companies Include:

**Crypto/Web3:**
- Protocol Labs, Filecoin, Open Zeppelin, Radicle
- The firm's most prominent foray into crypto began in 2016 with a check into Protocol Labs, the maker of Filecoin.

**Biology/Healthcare:**
- bit.bio, ZeroPhase, and Ethgas within the Biotechnology, Wireless Communications Equipment, and Financial Services industries. BlueYard Capital's latest investment was on 09-Jan-2026 in bit.bio, a company within the Biotechnology industry.
- BitBio or Biofidelity), new economic operating systems ‚Äî i.e. vertical software connected through open APIs vs monopoly bundleware (e.g. Pitch) and breakthrough engineering efforts (e.g. Marvel Fusion or Seeqc).

**Other Notable Investments:**
- Its portfolio spans crypto startups like Protocol Labs, the makers of Filecoin, to the missile maker Castelion.
- Its portfolio spans crypto startups like Protocol Labs, the makers of Filecoin, to the missile maker Castelion.

**Recent Portfolio Activity:**
- Their portfolio company Privy's acquisition by Stripe in June of last year as well as a sizable position in Solana have also led to early liquidity in the second fund.

### Geographic Distribution:
The portfolio is located in Amsterdam, Berlin, Bratislava, Buenos Aires, Mexico City, Palo Alto, Prague, San Francisco, Stockholm and Warsaw, with many teams operating with decentralised global teams and no HQ.

## Partners & Team

### Founding Partners:
- **Ciar√°n O'Leary** (Co-Founder & General Partner): Ciar√°n O'Leary is a co-founder of BlueYard Capital, a $120m early stage fund based in Berlin that invests in founders decentralizing markets, empowering users and liberating data. Prior to founding BlueYard, Ciar√°n set-up Earlybird Venture Capital's Berlin office as a partner and before that was at The Carlyle Group.

- **Jason Whitmire** (Co-Founder & General Partner): As partners together at a separate fund, Earlybird Venture Capital, O'Leary and Whitmire wrote checks into mobile gaming startup Peak Games and the task manager Wunderlist during the early 2010s.

### Additional Partners:
- **Chad Fowler** (Partner & CTO): O'Leary and Whitmire hired their first outside GP, former Wunderlist CTO Chad Fowler, in 2021 to manage the team's crypto funds, which were spun out for regulatory compliance reasons that year.

- **David Byrd** (Partner): In the middle of Fund 2, investor David Byrd joined and brought in his portfolio of AI infrastructure deals including holdings into chipmaker Groq and the quantum computing startup IonQ.

- **Michael Wax** (General Partner): BlueYard's fifth and newest general partner, Michael Wax, had historically been an operator as the co-founder and CEO of the European logistics company Forto. Wax joined the team just two months ago.

### Current Team Structure:
Ciar√°n O'Leary ¬∑ David Byrd ¬∑ Mike Wax ¬∑ Jason Whitmire ¬∑ Tim Robinson ¬∑ Alejo Salles ¬∑ Peter Read ¬∑ Philipp Banhardt ¬∑ Trent McConaghy ¬∑ Operations ¬∑ Christine Fuchs ¬∑ Cristel Mayer ¬∑ Jonah Kaplan ¬∑ Lucille Swan ¬∑ Lukas H√§nle ¬∑ Mark Storey ¬∑ Molly Thessin ¬∑ Yenilee Iƒçagiƒá

## Firm Background

**Founded:** Founded in 2015, BlueYard Capital is a venture capital firm based in Berlin, Germany. (Note: Sources indicate both 2015 and 2016 as founding year, with 2016 being when they launched operations)

**Location:** BlueYard's headquarters is located in Berlin (Germany).

**Investment Philosophy:** The BlueYard team pride themselves on their track record of betting on soon-to-be hot categories years before they reach consensus with other investors. "When lots of other VCs say, oh, no, this is too early, or this will never be venture capital, then we say this is probably one for us," said O'Leary.

**Unique Approach:** The firm runs a publicly accessible Knowledge hub with technical research and hosts intimate "BlueYard Conversations" events for technical and societal leading minds, positioning itself as an open research node rather than a typical capital provider.

## Investment Sectors

The firm seeks to invest in seed and early-stage companies operating in the technology, computation & intelligence, engineering, aerospace, defense, biology, cryptocurrency, and chemistry sectors.

BlueYard has a diverse portfolio, with companies operating in the High Tech, Enterprise Applications, Blockchain Technology, Enterprise Infrastructure and Life Sciences. Notably, it has invested in 55 Tech companies, 47 Enterprise (B2B) companies, 23 Blockchain companies and at least 23 companies focusing on Consumer (B2C).

This comprehensive research shows BlueYard Capital as a thesis-driven venture capital firm with a focus on "fabric-layer" technologies that can shape the future, strong performance metrics, and a diverse portfolio spanning crypto, biotech, AI infrastructure, and defense technologies.

## Blueprints Definitions

<blueprint>
  You are an analyst that does research tasks using tools that scrape the web and create structured data.
  Structured data extraction is an experimental feature -- only enable it if the user explicitly requests it in the prompt.
  Prefer updating existing notes instead of creating new ones.
  
  <strcutured_mode>
    When you are done, reply with the created objects.
    Do not print the data, instead reply with inline references to the created objects.
    Those will be later substituted with the pills representing the created objects.
    Print the rest of the created objects as block references after the main note.
  
    <example>
      Based on my research, Google was founded by @dxn:queue:data:B6INSIBY3CBEF4M5VZRYBCMAHQMPYK5AJ:01K24XMVHSZHS97SG1VTVQDM5Z:01K24XPK464FSCKVQJAB2H662M and @dxn:queue:data:B6INSIBY3CBEF4M5VZRYBCMAHQMPYK5AJ:01K24XMVHSZHS97SG1VTVQDM5Z:01K24XPK46K31DDW62PBW9H2ZQ

    </example>
  </structured_mode>
  
  <unstructured_mode>
    Reply normally with the text mode of the result of your research.
  </unstructured_mode>
</blueprint>

<blueprint>
  You can create, read and update markdown documents.
  When asked to edit or update documents return updates as a set of compact diff string pairs.
  For each diff, respond with the smallest possible matching span.
  
  Example:
  ```diff

  ```
</blueprint>

content.content:
You are the Research Agent.

The Research Agent is an expert assistant that conducts in-depth research using real-time web search.
The Research Agent outputs results in a structured format matching the schema provided.

The Research Agent is equipped with the ability to:

- Generate precise and effective search queries 
- Request web pages by query.
- Synthesize accurate, clear, and structured answers using reliable information from the retrieved content

The Research Agent always follows these principles:

- Relevance First: The Research Agent only returns facts supported by content in retrieved web pages. The Research Agent never fabricates or guesses information.
- Summarize, Don't Copy: The Research Agent synthesizes and rephrases content in its own words. The Research Agent quotes only when necessary.
- Multiple Sources: The Research Agent cross-references at least 2 sources before drawing conclusions, unless the information is directly stated and non-controversial.
- Transparency: The Research Agent mentions which sources were used and explains how it arrived at conclusions.
- Accuracy Over Brevity: The Research Agent prefers detailed, technically accurate explanations over shallow summaries.
- The Research Agent admits uncertainty rather than misleading.

The Research Agent may be asked for:

- Technical explanations
- Literature reviews  
- Comparisons
- Emerging trends
- Implementation strategies

The Research Agent begins by interpreting the user's request, then:

The Research Agent breaks it into sub-questions (if applicable).

For each sub-question, the Research Agent generates a clear, concise web search query.

The Research Agent extracts and synthesizes relevant answers.

The Research Agent's output includes:

- A clear, structured answer to the user's question
- A citation list or link list of sources used

Optionally, the Research Agent provides follow-up suggestions or questions for deeper inquiry.

Here's how the Research Agent operates:

1. The Research Agent analyzes the user's request and identifies key topics to search for (3 or more), printing them out.
2. The Research Agent performs a web search for each topic.
3. The Research Agent reads and analyzes results, cross references information from multiple sources, and represents conflicting information as ranges of possible values.

Status reporting:

The Research Agent reports its status frequently using the `<status>` tags: <status>Searching for Google Founders</status>
The Research Agent reports its status in-between each tool call and before submitting results.

Last content block is the full research note -- the result of the research.
BlueYard capital venture capital firm

result.document:
# Research Report: BlueYard Capital

## Overview

BlueYard Capital is a venture capital firm founded in 2016 and based in Berlin, Germany. The firm is described as "a small and equal partnership based in the US and Europe, founded in 2016, managing $500M in AuM, and deploying our third fund". BlueYard invests $500K ‚Äì $5M in pre-seed to Series A rounds as a lead or co-lead investor.

## Investment Philosophy

BlueYard Capital operates with a distinct investment thesis focused on transformative technologies. At BlueYard, they "invest in only two kinds of technologies: those that move us toward utopia, and those that hold the line against oblivion". BlueYard invests in founders with transforming ideas that decentralize markets and empower humanity.

The firm focuses on "fabric-layer" technologies‚Äîdeep infrastructure in computation, biology, engineering, and crypto that can become the interconnected elements of our future. They have organized their investment thesis around three specific fundamental forces‚Äîdecentralisation of markets, democratisation of capabilities, and liberation of data.

## Leadership Team

BlueYard was co-founded by Ciar√°n O'Leary and Jason Whitmire. Both founders previously worked together as partners at Earlybird Venture Capital, where they wrote checks into mobile gaming startup Peak Games and the task manager Wunderlist during the early 2010s. Peak Games eventually sold to Zynga for $1.8 billion, with Wunderlist being acquired by Microsoft for an undisclosed amount, generating roughly $500 million in cash proceeds.

The team has expanded over time: O'Leary and Whitmire hired their first outside GP, former Wunderlist CTO Chad Fowler, in 2021 to manage the team's crypto funds. David Byrd joined and brought in his portfolio of AI infrastructure deals including holdings into chipmaker Groq and the quantum computing startup IonQ. BlueYard's fifth and newest general partner, Michael Wax, had historically been an operator as the co-founder and CEO of the European logistics company Forto and joined the team just two months ago.

## Investment Focus Areas

BlueYard Capital's portfolio spans several key sectors:

### Crypto/Web3
Most active in crypto / web 3 (e.g. Protocol Labs, Filecoin, Open Zeppelin, Radicle). Its portfolio spans crypto startups like Protocol Labs, the makers of Filecoin, to the missile maker Castelion.

### Biology and Healthcare
Frontier biology to help us live long and prosper (e.g. BitBio, Biofidelity) and technologies that help us overcome our largest planetary challenges (e.g. Marvel Fusion, Meatable, Dance).

### Computing and Engineering
They invest in applied computation fueling technological breakthroughs enabling a safe, stable, and prosperous world to come ‚Äì fabric-layer applications and functionality most people won't ever see or know about.

### Additional Sectors
The firm seeks to invest in seed and early-stage companies operating in the technology, computation & intelligence, engineering, aerospace, defense, biology, cryptocurrency, and chemistry sectors.

## Performance and Financials

BlueYard has demonstrated strong performance, particularly with their first fund:

BlueYard's first ‚Ç¨111 million fund from 2016 is a standout. With a gross IRR of 76%, Net IRR of 49%, and DPI of 3.4x, it's more than tripled what LPs put into it. In UTIMCO's portfolio, BlueYard Fund I from 2016 held a 53% IRR in 2024, making it one of the highest performing fund vintages across their entire portfolio.

The firm's most prominent foray into crypto began in 2016 with a check into Protocol Labs, the maker of Filecoin. Sequoia Capital, a16z, and Union Square Ventures purchased a large stake in the token pre-sale in 2017, which ended up raising $205 million in its Initial Coin Offering.

## Investment Activity

As of Dec 2025, BlueYard is an active investor, having invested in 68 companies, with 4 new investments in the last 12 months. BlueYard primarily invests in Seed and Series A stages, and there are 2 unicorns in BlueYard's portfolio.

Top sectors in BlueYard's portfolio are High Tech (29 investments) and Blockchain Technology (23 investments).

## Investment Strategy

The BlueYard team pride themselves on their track record of betting on soon-to-be hot categories years before they reach consensus with other investors. "When lots of other VCs say, oh, no, this is too early, or this will never be venture capital, then we say this is probably one for us," said O'Leary.

Since launching the fund, they've backed some of venture's trendiest sectors ‚Äî crypto, AI infrastructure, and defense tech ‚Äî all before they've hit a fever pitch in the markets.

## Fund Structure

BlueYard's crypto funds are broken out and run as separate funds from their core funds for regulatory and tax reasons. BlueYard Capital has raised a total of $500M across 4 funds, their latest being BlueYard Capital Fund 3.

## Additional Activities

Beyond investing, the firm runs a publicly accessible Knowledge hub with technical research and hosts intimate "BlueYard Conversations" events for technical and societal leading minds, positioning itself as an open research node rather than a typical capital provider.

# Research Report: BlueYard Capital

## Overview

BlueYard Capital is a venture capital firm founded in 2016 and based in Berlin, Germany. The firm is described as "a small and equal partnership based in the US and Europe, founded in 2016, managing $500M in AuM, and deploying our third fund". BlueYard invests $500K ‚Äì $5M in pre-seed to Series A rounds as a lead or co-lead investor.

## Investment Philosophy

BlueYard Capital operates with a distinct investment thesis focused on transformative technologies. At BlueYard, they "invest in only two kinds of technologies: those that move us toward utopia, and those that hold the line against oblivion". BlueYard invests in founders with transforming ideas that decentralize markets and empower humanity.

The firm focuses on "fabric-layer" technologies‚Äîdeep infrastructure in computation, biology, engineering, and crypto that can become the interconnected elements of our future. They have organized their investment thesis around three specific fundamental forces‚Äîdecentralisation of markets, democratisation of capabilities, and liberation of data.

## Leadership Team

BlueYard was co-founded by Ciar√°n O'Leary and Jason Whitmire. Both founders previously worked together as partners at Earlybird Venture Capital, where they wrote checks into mobile gaming startup Peak Games and the task manager Wunderlist during the early 2010s. Peak Games eventually sold to Zynga for $1.8 billion, with Wunderlist being acquired by Microsoft for an undisclosed amount, generating roughly $500 million in cash proceeds.

The team has expanded over time: O'Leary and Whitmire hired their first outside GP, former Wunderlist CTO Chad Fowler, in 2021 to manage the team's crypto funds. David Byrd joined and brought in his portfolio of AI infrastructure deals including holdings into chipmaker Groq and the quantum computing startup IonQ. BlueYard's fifth and newest general partner, Michael Wax, had historically been an operator as the co-founder and CEO of the European logistics company Forto and joined the team just two months ago.

## Investment Focus Areas

BlueYard Capital's portfolio spans several key sectors:

### Crypto/Web3
Most active in crypto / web 3 (e.g. Protocol Labs, Filecoin, Open Zeppelin, Radicle). Its portfolio spans crypto startups like Protocol Labs, the makers of Filecoin, to the missile maker Castelion.

### Biology and Healthcare
Frontier biology to help us live long and prosper (e.g. BitBio, Biofidelity) and technologies that help us overcome our largest planetary challenges (e.g. Marvel Fusion, Meatable, Dance).

### Computing and Engineering
They invest in applied computation fueling technological breakthroughs enabling a safe, stable, and prosperous world to come ‚Äì fabric-layer applications and functionality most people won't ever see or know about.

### Additional Sectors
The firm seeks to invest in seed and early-stage companies operating in the technology, computation & intelligence, engineering, aerospace, defense, biology, cryptocurrency, and chemistry sectors.

## Performance and Financials

BlueYard has demonstrated strong performance, particularly with their first fund:

BlueYard's first ‚Ç¨111 million fund from 2016 is a standout. With a gross IRR of 76%, Net IRR of 49%, and DPI of 3.4x, it's more than tripled what LPs put into it. In UTIMCO's portfolio, BlueYard Fund I from 2016 held a 53% IRR in 2024, making it one of the highest performing fund vintages across their entire portfolio.

The firm's most prominent foray into crypto began in 2016 with a check into Protocol Labs, the maker of Filecoin. Sequoia Capital, a16z, and Union Square Ventures purchased a large stake in the token pre-sale in 2017, which ended up raising $205 million in its Initial Coin Offering.

## Investment Activity

As of Dec 2025, BlueYard is an active investor, having invested in 68 companies, with 4 new investments in the last 12 months. BlueYard primarily invests in Seed and Series A stages, and there are 2 unicorns in BlueYard's portfolio.

Top sectors in BlueYard's portfolio are High Tech (29 investments) and Blockchain Technology (23 investments).

## Investment Strategy

The BlueYard team pride themselves on their track record of betting on soon-to-be hot categories years before they reach consensus with other investors. "When lots of other VCs say, oh, no, this is too early, or this will never be venture capital, then we say this is probably one for us," said O'Leary.

Since launching the fund, they've backed some of venture's trendiest sectors ‚Äî crypto, AI infrastructure, and defense tech ‚Äî all before they've hit a fever pitch in the markets.

## Fund Structure

BlueYard's crypto funds are broken out and run as separate funds from their core funds for regulatory and tax reasons. BlueYard Capital has raised a total of $500M across 4 funds, their latest being BlueYard Capital Fund 3.

## Additional Activities

Beyond investing, the firm runs a publicly accessible Knowledge hub with technical research and hosts intimate "BlueYard Conversations" events for technical and societal leading minds, positioning itself as an open research node rather than a typical capital provider.

content.text: Now I'll create a research document summarizing this information about BlueYard.

# Research Report: BlueYard Capital

## Overview

BlueYard Capital is a venture capital firm founded in 2016 and based in Berlin, Germany. The firm is described as "a small and equal partnership based in the US and Europe, founded in 2016, managing $500M in AuM, and deploying our third fund". BlueYard invests $500K ‚Äì $5M in pre-seed to Series A rounds as a lead or co-lead investor.

## Investment Philosophy

BlueYard Capital operates with a distinct investment thesis focused on transformative technologies. At BlueYard, they "invest in only two kinds of technologies: those that move us toward utopia, and those that hold the line against oblivion". BlueYard invests in founders with transforming ideas that decentralize markets and empower humanity.

The firm focuses on "fabric-layer" technologies‚Äîdeep infrastructure in computation, biology, engineering, and crypto that can become the interconnected elements of our future. They have organized their investment thesis around three specific fundamental forces‚Äîdecentralisation of markets, democratisation of capabilities, and liberation of data.

## Leadership Team

BlueYard was co-founded by Ciar√°n O'Leary and Jason Whitmire. Both founders previously worked together as partners at Earlybird Venture Capital, where they wrote checks into mobile gaming startup Peak Games and the task manager Wunderlist during the early 2010s. Peak Games eventually sold to Zynga for $1.8 billion, with Wunderlist being acquired by Microsoft for an undisclosed amount, generating roughly $500 million in cash proceeds.

The team has expanded over time: O'Leary and Whitmire hired their first outside GP, former Wunderlist CTO Chad Fowler, in 2021 to manage the team's crypto funds. David Byrd joined and brought in his portfolio of AI infrastructure deals including holdings into chipmaker Groq and the quantum computing startup IonQ. BlueYard's fifth and newest general partner, Michael Wax, had historically been an operator as the co-founder and CEO of the European logistics company Forto and joined the team just two months ago.

## Investment Focus Areas

BlueYard Capital's portfolio spans several key sectors:

### Crypto/Web3
Most active in crypto / web 3 (e.g. Protocol Labs, Filecoin, Open Zeppelin, Radicle). Its portfolio spans crypto startups like Protocol Labs, the makers of Filecoin, to the missile maker Castelion.

### Biology and Healthcare
Frontier biology to help us live long and prosper (e.g. BitBio, Biofidelity) and technologies that help us overcome our largest planetary challenges (e.g. Marvel Fusion, Meatable, Dance).

### Computing and Engineering
They invest in applied computation fueling technological breakthroughs enabling a safe, stable, and prosperous world to come ‚Äì fabric-layer applications and functionality most people won't ever see or know about.

### Additional Sectors
The firm seeks to invest in seed and early-stage companies operating in the technology, computation & intelligence, engineering, aerospace, defense, biology, cryptocurrency, and chemistry sectors.

## Performance and Financials

BlueYard has demonstrated strong performance, particularly with their first fund:

BlueYard's first ‚Ç¨111 million fund from 2016 is a standout. With a gross IRR of 76%, Net IRR of 49%, and DPI of 3.4x, it's more than tripled what LPs put into it. In UTIMCO's portfolio, BlueYard Fund I from 2016 held a 53% IRR in 2024, making it one of the highest performing fund vintages across their entire portfolio.

The firm's most prominent foray into crypto began in 2016 with a check into Protocol Labs, the maker of Filecoin. Sequoia Capital, a16z, and Union Square Ventures purchased a large stake in the token pre-sale in 2017, which ended up raising $205 million in its Initial Coin Offering.

## Investment Activity

As of Dec 2025, BlueYard is an active investor, having invested in 68 companies, with 4 new investments in the last 12 months. BlueYard primarily invests in Seed and Series A stages, and there are 2 unicorns in BlueYard's portfolio.

Top sectors in BlueYard's portfolio are High Tech (29 investments) and Blockchain Technology (23 investments).

## Investment Strategy

The BlueYard team pride themselves on their track record of betting on soon-to-be hot categories years before they reach consensus with other investors. "When lots of other VCs say, oh, no, this is too early, or this will never be venture capital, then we say this is probably one for us," said O'Leary.

Since launching the fund, they've backed some of venture's trendiest sectors ‚Äî crypto, AI infrastructure, and defense tech ‚Äî all before they've hit a fever pitch in the markets.

## Fund Structure

BlueYard's crypto funds are broken out and run as separate funds from their core funds for regulatory and tax reasons. BlueYard Capital has raised a total of $500M across 4 funds, their latest being BlueYard Capital Fund 3.

## Additional Activities

Beyond investing, the firm runs a publicly accessible Knowledge hub with technical research and hosts intimate "BlueYard Conversations" events for technical and societal leading minds, positioning itself as an open research node rather than a typical capital provider.

# BlueYard Capital Research Summary

## Company Overview

BlueYard Capital is a Berlin-based venture capital firm founded in 2016 by Ciar√°n O'Leary and Jason Whitmire. The firm manages $500M in assets under management (AUM) and is currently deploying its third fund. BlueYard operates as a small, equal partnership with presence in both the US and Europe.

## Investment Philosophy

BlueYard distinguishes itself with a unique investment thesis focused on transformative technologies. The firm invests in:
- Technologies that "move us toward utopia" or "hold the line against oblivion"
- Founders with transforming ideas that decentralize markets and empower humanity
- "Fabric-layer" technologies‚Äîdeep infrastructure in computation, biology, engineering, and crypto

Their investment approach is organized around three fundamental forces:
1. Decentralization of markets
2. Democratization of capabilities
3. Liberation of data

## Investment Parameters

- **Stage**: Pre-seed to Series A
- **Check Size**: $500K - $5M
- **Role**: Lead or co-lead investor
- **Portfolio**: 68 companies invested, including 2 unicorns
- **Recent Activity**: 4 new investments in the last 12 months

## Key Focus Areas

### Crypto/Web3
- Most active sector for BlueYard
- Notable investments: Protocol Labs (Filecoin), OpenZeppelin, Radicle
- Separate crypto funds managed for regulatory and tax reasons

### Biology and Healthcare
- Frontier biology for longevity
- Planetary challenge solutions
- Portfolio includes: BitBio, Biofidelity, Meatable, Dance

### Computing and Engineering
- Applied computation for technological breakthroughs
- Defense technology (e.g., Castelion missile maker)
- AI infrastructure (e.g., Groq chipmaker, IonQ quantum computing)

## Leadership Team

- **Ciar√°n O'Leary** - Co-founder
- **Jason Whitmire** - Co-founder
- **Chad Fowler** - GP (joined 2021, former Wunderlist CTO, manages crypto funds)
- **David Byrd** - GP (AI infrastructure focus)
- **Michael Wax** - GP (joined recently, former Forto co-founder/CEO)

## Performance Highlights

BlueYard's first fund (‚Ç¨111 million, 2016 vintage) has delivered exceptional returns:
- **Gross IRR**: 76%
- **Net IRR**: 49%
- **DPI**: 3.4x
- Ranked among highest performing fund vintages in UTIMCO's portfolio (53% IRR in 2024)

## Notable Successes

The founders' track record includes:
- **Peak Games**: Sold to Zynga for $1.8 billion
- **Wunderlist**: Acquired by Microsoft
- **Protocol Labs**: Major crypto success with Filecoin ICO raising $205 million

## Investment Strategy

BlueYard prides itself on identifying categories years before they reach consensus:
- Early bets on crypto, AI infrastructure, and defense tech
- Contrarian approach: "When lots of other VCs say this is too early... we say this is probably one for us"
- Focus on non-obvious, transformative technologies

## Additional Activities

- Operates a public Knowledge hub with technical research
- Hosts "BlueYard Conversations" events for technical and societal leaders
- Positions itself as an open research node beyond traditional capital provision
